intro: Diplostephium apiculatum, commonly known as the hooked spurge, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family and is characterized by its unique, spiny stems and small, inconspicuous flowers. The plant produces a milky latex when damaged, which is a common trait among members of its family. It thrives in disturbed soils and can often be found in open habitats such as grasslands and along roadsides. Its growth habit and appearance make it both ecologically significant and sometimes invasive in certain regions.
